sen.j: 所従（しょじゅう）とは中世の日本に存在した隷属身分の一。
sen.e: Shoju (followers) was a category of slave which existed in Medieval Japan.

sen.j: 本来は「従者」の意味であり、貴人・武家・寺社・有力農民などに付属して、雑務労役を担い、譲渡や相続の対象となった。
sen.e: Shoju originally meant 'subordinates,' but in fact, those in this category were owned by others such as the nobleman, military family, temples and shrines, and propertied farmer for servile labors, and were regarded as properties to be transferred or inherited.

sen.j: 同類身分として「下人」があり、「下人・所従」と総称されることが多いが、下人は「百姓下人」などと上層農民に付属する隷属民を指すのに対し、所従は「地頭所従」などと主に武家の隷属民を指すことが多かった。
sen.e: There existed 'Genin' (underlings) as a close parallel to Shoju and two of them were often used in pair as 'Genin - Shoju' -- Generally, Genin meant the slaves subordinate to upper class farmers and was called 'Hyakusho Genin' (Genin of farmers), while Shoju meant the slaves of a military family and was called 'Jito Genin' (Genin of jito (manager and lord of manor).)

sen.j: ただ、実際は明らかに下人と同一階層の身分を「所従」と呼ぶこともあり、用法に厳格な違いはなく混用されていた。
sen.e: However, in practice, as those definitely in the class of Genin were sometimes called 'Shoju', the two designations were used interchangeably with no significant differences in usage.

sen.j: 所従の中には一家を構えて自営耕作を行うものもおり、その身分的実態は一律ではなかった。
sen.e: As some of Shoju even had their own independent households and families and cultivated their lands independently, Shoju was not a uniformly established class in reality.

sen.j: 系譜としては奈良時代以前の「家人（けにん）」の流れを引くものであり、主家へ累代一身専属するのが普通であった。
sen.e: Shoju was descended from 'Kenin' (houseman) which existed before the Nara period, and usually belonged to the master's house by themselves from generation to generation.

sen.j: 武家に付随する所従は合戦において戦場に同行し、馬の口引き、敵の首担ぎなどの職責を担ったが、通常士分とは認められておらずその首を取っても手柄とは見なされなかった。
sen.e: As Shoju were subordinate to the military family, they attended their master to battlefields in wartime for such labors as packhorse driving or carrying of an enemy's head -- Nevertheless, they were not regarded as samurai warriors, and even if they took their enemy's head, it was not considered as their military achievement.

sen.j: 近世以降、所従の語は余り使われなくなり隷属民の呼称としては武家、農家にかかわらず下人の称が多く用いられるようになった。
sen.e: After the early-modern times, the designation Shoju became gradually obsolete, while the word Genin became used frequently as a designation of slaves whether their masters were military families or farmers.
